Page.title: Check NPM version
Page._content:
Enforces "peer" npm dependencies in Meteor packages.

Use this package if you are writing an Meteor package that depends on a given npm package is installed at the app level of projects you are installed in.

## Managers
* [Kelly Copley](https://github.com/sponsors/copleykj)

## Package
* [GitHub repository](https://github.com/Meteor-Community-Packages/check-npm-versions)

Page.title: Collection 2
Page._content:
A Meteor package that allows you to attach a schema to a Mongo.Collection. Automatically validates against that schema when inserting and updating from client or server code.

This package requires the [simpl-schema NPM package](https://github.com/aldeed/simple-schema-js), which defines the schema syntax and provides the validation logic.

## Managers
* [Eric Dobbertin](https://github.com/sponsors/aldeed)
* [Jan Dvorak](https://github.com/sponsors/StorytellerCZ)
* [Kelly Copley](https://github.com/sponsors/copleykj)
* [Harry Adel](https://github.com/harryadel)

## Packages
- [GitHub repository](https://github.com/Meteor-Community-Packages/meteor-collection2)
- [Atmosphere](https://atmospherejs.com/aldeed/collection2)

Page.title: Collection Hooks
Page._content:
Extends Mongo.Collection with `before`/`after` hooks for `insert`, `update`, `remove`, `find`, and `findOne`.

Works across client, server or a mix. Also works when a client initiates a collection method and the server runs the hook, all while respecting the collection validators (allow/deny).

## Managers
* [Seba Kerchhof](https://github.com/sebakerckhof)
* [Jan Dvorak](https://github.com/sponsors/StorytellerCZ)
* [Simon Fridlund](https://github.com/sponsors/zimme)
* [Kelly Copley](https://github.com/sponsors/copleykj/)

## Packages
* [GitHub repository](https://github.com/Meteor-Community-Packages/meteor-collection-hooks)
* [Atmosphere](https://atmospherejs.com/matb33/collection-hooks)
* [Packosphere](https://packosphere.com/matb33/collection-hooks)

Page.title: Fast Render
Page._content:
Fast Render is back!

Fast Render can improve the initial load time of your app, giving you 2-10 times faster initial page loads. It provides the same effect as Server Side Rendering (SSR), but still sends data over the wire to avoid breaking one of Meteor’s core principles.

> This is a continuation of meteorhacks:fast-render by @arunoda

## Managers
* [Kelly Copley](https://github.com/sponsors/copleykj)

## Package
* [GitHub repository](https://github.com/Meteor-Community-Packages/meteor-fast-render)
* [Packosphere](https://packosphere.com/communitypackages/fast-render)

Page.title: Introduction
Page.description: Why and what packages does MCP take care of?
Page._content:
The main purpose of Meteor Community Packages is to maintain and develop major community packages that the original owner no longer wishes to or can maintain or wants it to be in the community domain.

* [GitHub organization](https://github.com/Meteor-Community-Packages)

Page.title: Standard Minifier for CSS + autoprefixing
Page._content:
This package provides a minifier plugin used for Meteor apps by default and adds autoprefixing to it.

The CSS minifier mostly reduces amount of white-space parsing CSS with ParseCSS.

Page.title: Picker
Page._content:

Page.title: PostCSS
Page._content:
Meteor CSS Minifier with PostCSS processing.

This package allows you to use [PostCSS](https://github.com/postcss/postcss) plugins with .css files. You can add your custom plugins by adding Npm packages using `package.json`. You can also use your favourite preprocessor side by side with this package. It allows you to enable many PostCSS plugins, for example Autoprefixer for all preprocessors you use. (Of course you can use it whithout any preprocessor too).

## Managers
* [Kelly Copley](https://github.com/sponsors/copleykj/)
* [Mitar](https://github.com/sponsors/mitar)

## Repository
* [GitHub repository](https://github.com/Meteor-Community-Packages/meteor-postcss)

Page.title: Publish composite
Page.description: Push notifications for Cordova and browser
Page._content:
`publishComposite(...)` provides a flexible way to publish a set of related documents from various collections using a reactive join. This makes it easy to publish a whole tree of documents at once. The published collections are reactive and will update when additions/changes/deletions are made.

This project differs from many other parent/child relationship mappers in its flexibility. The relationship between a parent and its children can be based on almost anything. For example, let's say you have a site that displays news articles. On each article page, you would like to display a list at the end containing a couple of related articles. You could use `publishComposite` to publish the primary article, scan the body for keywords which are then used to search for other articles, and publish these related articles as children. Of course, the keyword extraction and searching are up to you to implement.

## Managers
* [Sean Dwyer](https://github.com/reywood)
* [Jan Dvorak](https://github.com/sponsors/StorytellerCZ)
* [Kelly Copley](https://github.com/sponsors/copleykj)

## Package
* [GitHub repository](https://github.com/Meteor-Community-Packages/meteor-publish-composite)
* [Packosphere](https://packosphere.com/reywood/publish-composite)

Page.title: Stratosphere
Page._content:
Stratosphere is a private package server for Meteor. So this is like Atmosphere on your own servers, with private packages.

Besides your own packages, Stratosphere will also give you access to all packages on Atmosphere.

At any time you can switch between package servers by setting an environment variable.

* [Mitar](https://github.com/sponsors/mitar)

* [Kelly Copley](https://github.com/sponsors/copleykj/)

Page.title: User status
Page.description: Push notifications for Cordova and browser
Page._content:
Keeps track of user connection data, such as IP addresses, user agents, and client-side activity, and tracks this information in `Meteor.users` as well as some other objects. This allows you to easily see users that are online, for applications such as rendering the users box below showing online users in green and idle users in orange.

## Managers
* [Andrew Mao](https://github.com/mizzao)

* [GitHub repository](https://github.com/Meteor-Community-Packages/meteor-user-status)

Page._content:
## Manager
* [Testing team](https://github.com/orgs/Meteor-Community-Packages/teams/testing)

## Description
Previously knows as `meteortesting`, is now part of Community Packages. These include 3 packages for testing in Meteor with Mocha:

* [Mocha](https://github.com/Meteor-Community-Packages/meteor-mocha)
* [Meteor Browser Tests](https://github.com/Meteor-Community-Packages/meteor-browser-tests)
* [Mocha Core](https://github.com/Meteor-Community-Packages/meteor-mocha-core)
Page.raw:
---
title: Testing
description: Packages for testing in Meteor
---

## Manager
* [Testing team](https://github.com/orgs/Meteor-Community-Packages/teams/testing)

## Description
Previously knows as `meteortesting`, is now part of Community Packages. These include 3 packages for testing in Meteor with Mocha:

* [Mocha](https://github.com/Meteor-Community-Packages/meteor-mocha)
* [Meteor Browser Tests](https://github.com/Meteor-Community-Packages/meteor-browser-tests)
* [Mocha Core](https://github.com/Meteor-Community-Packages/meteor-mocha-core)

Page.title: Check NPM version
Page._content:
Enforces "peer" npm dependencies in Meteor packages.

Use this package if you are writing an Meteor package that depends on a given npm package is installed at the app level of projects you are installed in.

## Managers
* [Kelly Copley](https://github.com/sponsors/copleykj)

Page.title: Collection Hooks
Page._content:
Extends Mongo.Collection with `before`/`after` hooks for `insert`, `update`, `remove`, `find`, and `findOne`.

Works across client, server or a mix. Also works when a client initiates a collection method and the server runs the hook, all while respecting the collection validators (allow/deny).

Page.title: Collection 2
Page._content:
A Meteor package that allows you to attach a schema to a Mongo.Collection. Automatically validates against that schema when inserting and updating from client or server code.

Page.title: Fast Render
Page._content:
Fast Render is back!

Fast Render can improve the initial load time of your app, giving you 2-10 times faster initial page loads. It provides the same effect as Server Side Rendering (SSR), but still sends data over the wire to avoid breaking one of Meteor’s core principles.

> This is a continuation of meteorhacks:fast-render by @arunoda

## Managers
* [Kelly Copley](https://github.com/sponsors/copleykj)

Page.title: PostCSS
Page._content:
Meteor CSS Minifier with PostCSS processing.

This package allows you to use [PostCSS](https://github.com/postcss/postcss) plugins with .css files. You can add your custom plugins by adding Npm packages using `package.json`. You can also use your favourite preprocessor side by side with this package. It allows you to enable many PostCSS plugins, for example Autoprefixer for all preprocessors you use. (Of course you can use it whithout any preprocessor too).

Page.title: Publish composite
Page.description: Push notifications for Cordova and browser
Page._content:
`publishComposite(...)` provides a flexible way to publish a set of related documents from various collections using a reactive join. This makes it easy to publish a whole tree of documents at once. The published collections are reactive and will update when additions/changes/deletions are made.

This project differs from many other parent/child relationship mappers in its flexibility. The relationship between a parent and its children can be based on almost anything. For example, let's say you have a site that displays news articles. On each article page, you would like to display a list at the end containing a couple of related articles. You could use `publishComposite` to publish the primary article, scan the body for keywords which are then used to search for other articles, and publish these related articles as children. Of course, the keyword extraction and searching are up to you to implement.

## Managers
* [Sean Dwyer](https://github.com/reywood)
* [Jan Dvorak](https://github.com/sponsors/StorytellerCZ)
* [Kelly Copley](https://github.com/sponsors/copleykj)

## Package
* [GitHub repository](https://github.com/Meteor-Community-Packages/meteor-publish-composite)
* [Packosphere](https://packosphere.com/reywood/publish-composite)
Page.raw:
---
title: Publish composite
description: Push notifications for Cordova and browser
---

`publishComposite(...)` provides a flexible way to publish a set of related documents from various collections using a reactive join. This makes it easy to publish a whole tree of documents at once. The published collections are reactive and will update when additions/changes/deletions are made.

This project differs from many other parent/child relationship mappers in its flexibility. The relationship between a parent and its children can be based on almost anything. For example, let's say you have a site that displays news articles. On each article page, you would like to display a list at the end containing a couple of related articles. You could use `publishComposite` to publish the primary article, scan the body for keywords which are then used to search for other articles, and publish these related articles as children. Of course, the keyword extraction and searching are up to you to implement.

## Managers
* [Sean Dwyer](https://github.com/reywood)
* [Jan Dvorak](https://github.com/sponsors/StorytellerCZ)
* [Kelly Copley](https://github.com/sponsors/copleykj)

## Package
* [GitHub repository](https://github.com/Meteor-Community-Packages/meteor-publish-composite)
* [Packosphere](https://packosphere.com/reywood/publish-composite)
Page.content:
publishComposite(...) provides a flexible way to publish a set of related documents from various collections using a reactive join. This makes it easy to publish a whole tree of documents at once. The published collections are reactive and will update when additions/changes/deletions are made.

This project differs from many other parent/child relationship mappers in its flexibility. The relationship between a parent and its children can be based on almost anything. For example, let’s say you have a site that displays news articles. On each article page, you would like to display a list at the end containing a couple of related articles. You could use publishComposite to publish the primary article, scan the body for keywords which are then used to search for other articles, and publish these related articles as children. Of course, the keyword extraction and searching are up to you to implement.

Managers

  • Sean Dwyer
  • Jan Dvorak
  • Kelly Copley

Package

  • GitHub repository
  • Packosphere
Page.more:

Page.title: Stratosphere
Page._content:
Stratosphere is a private package server for Meteor. So this is like Atmosphere on your own servers, with private packages.

Besides your own packages, Stratosphere will also give you access to all packages on Atmosphere.

At any time you can switch between package servers by setting an environment variable.

Page.title: User status
Page.description: Push notifications for Cordova and browser
Page._content:
Keeps track of user connection data, such as IP addresses, user agents, and client-side activity, and tracks this information in `Meteor.users` as well as some other objects. This allows you to easily see users that are online, for applications such as rendering the users box below showing online users in green and idle users in orange.

## Managers
* [Andrew Mao](https://github.com/mizzao)

Page.title: Collection Hooks
Page._content:
Extends Mongo.Collection with `before`/`after` hooks for `insert`, `update`, `remove`, `find`, and `findOne`.

Works across client, server or a mix. Also works when a client initiates a collection method and the server runs the hook, all while respecting the collection validators (allow/deny).

Page.title: Collection 2
Page._content:
A Meteor package that allows you to attach a schema to a Mongo.Collection. Automatically validates against that schema when inserting and updating from client or server code.

This package requires the [simpl-schema NPM package](https://github.com/aldeed/simple-schema-js), which defines the schema syntax and provides the validation logic.

Page.title: Fast Render
Page._content:
Fast Render is back!

Fast Render can improve the initial load time of your app, giving you 2-10 times faster initial page loads. It provides the same effect as Server Side Rendering (SSR), but still sends data over the wire to avoid breaking one of Meteor’s core principles.

> This is a continuation of meteorhacks:fast-render by @arunoda

## Managers
* [Kelly Copley](https://github.com/sponsors/copleykj)

## Package
* [GitHub repository](https://github.com/Meteor-Community-Packages/meteor-fast-render)
* [Packosphere](https://packosphere.com/communitypackages/fast-render)

Page.title: Introduction
Page.description: Why and what packages does MCP take care of?
Page._content:
The main purpose of Meteor Community Packages is to maintain and develop major community packages that the original owner no longer wishes to or can maintain or wants it to be in the community domain.

* [GitHub organization](https://github.com/Meteor-Community-Packages)

Page.title: PostCSS
Page._content:
Meteor CSS Minifier with PostCSS processing.

This package allows you to use [PostCSS](https://github.com/postcss/postcss) plugins with .css files. You can add your custom plugins by adding Npm packages using `package.json`. You can also use your favourite preprocessor side by side with this package. It allows you to enable many PostCSS plugins, for example Autoprefixer for all preprocessors you use. (Of course you can use it whithout any preprocessor too).

## Managers
* [Kelly Copley](https://github.com/sponsors/copleykj/)
* [Mitar](https://github.com/sponsors/mitar)

## Repository
* [GitHub repository](https://github.com/Meteor-Community-Packages/meteor-postcss)

Page.title: Publish composite
Page.description: Push notifications for Cordova and browser
Page._content:
`publishComposite(...)` provides a flexible way to publish a set of related documents from various collections using a reactive join. This makes it easy to publish a whole tree of documents at once. The published collections are reactive and will update when additions/changes/deletions are made.

This project differs from many other parent/child relationship mappers in its flexibility. The relationship between a parent and its children can be based on almost anything. For example, let's say you have a site that displays news articles. On each article page, you would like to display a list at the end containing a couple of related articles. You could use `publishComposite` to publish the primary article, scan the body for keywords which are then used to search for other articles, and publish these related articles as children. Of course, the keyword extraction and searching are up to you to implement.

## Managers
* [Sean Dwyer](https://github.com/reywood)
* [Jan Dvorak](https://github.com/sponsors/StorytellerCZ)
* [Kelly Copley](https://github.com/sponsors/copleykj)

## Package
* [GitHub repository](https://github.com/Meteor-Community-Packages/meteor-publish-composite)
* [Packosphere](https://packosphere.com/reywood/publish-composite)

Page.title: Stratosphere
Page._content:
Stratosphere is a private package server for Meteor. So this is like Atmosphere on your own servers, with private packages.

Besides your own packages, Stratosphere will also give you access to all packages on Atmosphere.

At any time you can switch between package servers by setting an environment variable.

## Managers
* [Mitar](https://github.com/sponsors/mitar)
* [Seba Kerchhof](https://github.com/sebakerckhof)
* [Kelly Copley](https://github.com/sponsors/copleykj/)

Besides your own packages, Stratosphere will also give you access to all packages on Atmosphere.

At any time you can switch between package servers by setting an environment variable.

Managers

  • Mitar
  • Seba Kerchhof
  • Kelly Copley

Repository

  • GitHub repository

Page.title: User status
Page.description: Push notifications for Cordova and browser
Page._content:
Keeps track of user connection data, such as IP addresses, user agents, and client-side activity, and tracks this information in `Meteor.users` as well as some other objects. This allows you to easily see users that are online, for applications such as rendering the users box below showing online users in green and idle users in orange.

## Managers
* [Andrew Mao](https://github.com/mizzao)

## Package
* [GitHub repository](https://github.com/Meteor-Community-Packages/meteor-user-status)

Page.title: Collection Hooks
Page._content:
Extends Mongo.Collection with `before`/`after` hooks for `insert`, `update`, `remove`, `find`, and `findOne`.

Works across client, server or a mix. Also works when a client initiates a collection method and the server runs the hook, all while respecting the collection validators (allow/deny).

## Managers
* [Seba Kerchhof](https://github.com/sebakerckhof)
* [Jan Dvorak](https://github.com/sponsors/StorytellerCZ)
* [Simon Fridlund](https://github.com/sponsors/zimme)
* [Kelly Copley](https://github.com/sponsors/copleykj/)

## Pacakges
* [GitHub repository](https://github.com/Meteor-Community-Packages/meteor-collection-hooks)
* [Atmosphere](https://atmospherejs.com/matb33/collection-hooks)
* [Packosphere](https://packosphere.com/matb33/collection-hooks)

Page.title: Collection 2
Page._content:
A Meteor package that allows you to attach a schema to a Mongo.Collection. Automatically validates against that schema when inserting and updating from client or server code.

This package requires the [simpl-schema NPM package](https://github.com/aldeed/simple-schema-js), which defines the schema syntax and provides the validation logic.

## Managers
* [Eric Dobbertin](https://github.com/sponsors/aldeed)

* [Harry Adel](https://github.com/harryadel)

- [Atmosphere](https://atmospherejs.com/aldeed/collection2)

Page.title: Fast Render
Page._content:
Fast Render is back!

Fast Render can improve the initial load time of your app, giving you 2-10 times faster initial page loads. It provides the same effect as Server Side Rendering (SSR), but still sends data over the wire to avoid breaking one of Meteor’s core principles.

> This is a continuation of meteorhacks:fast-render by @arunoda

## Managers
* [Kelly Copley](https://github.com/sponsors/copleykj)

## Package
* [GitHub repository](https://github.com/Meteor-Community-Packages/meteor-fast-render)
* [Packosphere](https://packosphere.com/communitypackages/fast-render)

Page.title: PostCSS
Page._content:
Meteor CSS Minifier with PostCSS processing.

This package allows you to use [PostCSS](https://github.com/postcss/postcss) plugins with .css files. You can add your custom plugins by adding Npm packages using `package.json`. You can also use your favourite preprocessor side by side with this package. It allows you to enable many PostCSS plugins, for example Autoprefixer for all preprocessors you use. (Of course you can use it whithout any preprocessor too).

## Managers
* [Kelly Copley](https://github.com/sponsors/copleykj/)
* [Mitar](https://github.com/sponsors/mitar)

Page.title: Publish composite
Page.description: Push notifications for Cordova and browser
Page._content:
`publishComposite(...)` provides a flexible way to publish a set of related documents from various collections using a reactive join. This makes it easy to publish a whole tree of documents at once. The published collections are reactive and will update when additions/changes/deletions are made.

This project differs from many other parent/child relationship mappers in its flexibility. The relationship between a parent and its children can be based on almost anything. For example, let's say you have a site that displays news articles. On each article page, you would like to display a list at the end containing a couple of related articles. You could use `publishComposite` to publish the primary article, scan the body for keywords which are then used to search for other articles, and publish these related articles as children. Of course, the keyword extraction and searching are up to you to implement.

## Managers
* [Sean Dwyer](https://github.com/reywood)
* [Jan Dvorak](https://github.com/sponsors/StorytellerCZ)
* [Kelly Copley](https://github.com/sponsors/copleykj)

## Package
* [GitHub repository](https://github.com/Meteor-Community-Packages/meteor-publish-composite)
* [Packosphere](https://packosphere.com/reywood/publish-composite)

Page.title: Stratosphere
Page._content:
Stratosphere is a private package server for Meteor. So this is like Atmosphere on your own servers, with private packages.

Besides your own packages, Stratosphere will also give you access to all packages on Atmosphere.

At any time you can switch between package servers by setting an environment variable.

Page.title: User status
Page.description: Push notifications for Cordova and browser
Page._content:
Keeps track of user connection data, such as IP addresses, user agents, and client-side activity, and tracks this information in `Meteor.users` as well as some other objects. This allows you to easily see users that are online, for applications such as rendering the users box below showing online users in green and idle users in orange.

Page.title: Check NPM version
Page._content:
Enforces "peer" npm dependencies in Meteor packages.

Use this package if you are writing an Meteor package that depends on a given npm package is installed at the app level of projects you are installed in.

Page.title: Collection Hooks
Page._content:
Extends Mongo.Collection with `before`/`after` hooks for `insert`, `update`, `remove`, `find`, and `findOne`.

Works across client, server or a mix. Also works when a client initiates a collection method and the server runs the hook, all while respecting the collection validators (allow/deny).

## Managers
* [Seba Kerchhof](https://github.com/sebakerckhof)
* [Jan Dvorak](https://github.com/sponsors/StorytellerCZ)
* [Simon Fridlund](https://github.com/sponsors/zimme)
* [Kelly Copley](https://github.com/sponsors/copleykj/)

## Pacakges

* [Atmosphere](https://atmospherejs.com/matb33/collection-hooks)
* [Packosphere](https://packosphere.com/matb33/collection-hooks)

Page.title: Collection 2
Page._content:
A Meteor package that allows you to attach a schema to a Mongo.Collection. Automatically validates against that schema when inserting and updating from client or server code.

This package requires the [simpl-schema NPM package](https://github.com/aldeed/simple-schema-js), which defines the schema syntax and provides the validation logic.

## Managers
* [Eric Dobbertin](https://github.com/sponsors/aldeed)
* [Jan Dvorak](https://github.com/sponsors/StorytellerCZ)
* [Kelly Copley](https://github.com/sponsors/copleykj)
* [Harry Adel](https://github.com/harryadel)

## Pacakges
- [GitHub repository](https://github.com/Meteor-Community-Packages/meteor-collection2)
- [Atmosphere](https://atmospherejs.com/aldeed/collection2)

Page.title: Fast Render
Page._content:
Fast Render is back!

Fast Render can improve the initial load time of your app, giving you 2-10 times faster initial page loads. It provides the same effect as Server Side Rendering (SSR), but still sends data over the wire to avoid breaking one of Meteor’s core principles.

> This is a continuation of meteorhacks:fast-render by @arunoda

## Managers
* [Kelly Copley](https://github.com/sponsors/copleykj)

## Package
* [GitHub repository](https://github.com/Meteor-Community-Packages/meteor-fast-render)
* [Packosphere](https://packosphere.com/communitypackages/fast-render)

This package allows you to use [PostCSS](https://github.com/postcss/postcss) plugins with .css files. You can add your custom plugins by adding Npm packages using `package.json`. You can also use your favourite preprocessor side by side with this package. It allows you to enable many PostCSS plugins, for example Autoprefixer for all preprocessors you use. (Of course you can use it whithout any preprocessor too).

## Managers
* [Kelly Copley](https://github.com/sponsors/copleykj/)
* [Mitar](https://github.com/sponsors/mitar)

## Repository
* [GitHub repository](https://github.com/Meteor-Community-Packages/meteor-postcss)

Page.title: Publish composite
Page.description: Push notifications for Cordova and browser
Page._content:
`publishComposite(...)` provides a flexible way to publish a set of related documents from various collections using a reactive join. This makes it easy to publish a whole tree of documents at once. The published collections are reactive and will update when additions/changes/deletions are made.

This project differs from many other parent/child relationship mappers in its flexibility. The relationship between a parent and its children can be based on almost anything. For example, let's say you have a site that displays news articles. On each article page, you would like to display a list at the end containing a couple of related articles. You could use `publishComposite` to publish the primary article, scan the body for keywords which are then used to search for other articles, and publish these related articles as children. Of course, the keyword extraction and searching are up to you to implement.

## Managers
* [Sean Dwyer](https://github.com/reywood)
* [Jan Dvorak](https://github.com/sponsors/StorytellerCZ)
* [Kelly Copley](https://github.com/sponsors/copleykj)

## Package
* [GitHub repository](https://github.com/Meteor-Community-Packages/meteor-publish-composite)
* [Packosphere](https://packosphere.com/reywood/publish-composite)

Page.title: Stratosphere
Page._content:
Stratosphere is a private package server for Meteor. So this is like Atmosphere on your own servers, with private packages.

Besides your own packages, Stratosphere will also give you access to all packages on Atmosphere.

At any time you can switch between package servers by setting an environment variable.

* [Mitar](https://github.com/sponsors/mitar)

* [Kelly Copley](https://github.com/sponsors/copleykj/)

Page.title: User status
Page.description: Push notifications for Cordova and browser
Page._content:
Keeps track of user connection data, such as IP addresses, user agents, and client-side activity, and tracks this information in `Meteor.users` as well as some other objects. This allows you to easily see users that are online, for applications such as rendering the users box below showing online users in green and idle users in orange.

## Managers
* [Andrew Mao](https://github.com/mizzao)

## Package
* [GitHub repository](https://github.com/Meteor-Community-Packages/meteor-user-status)

Page.title: Collection Hooks
Page._content:
Extends Mongo.Collection with `before`/`after` hooks for `insert`, `update`, `remove`, `find`, and `findOne`.

Works across client, server or a mix. Also works when a client initiates a collection method and the server runs the hook, all while respecting the collection validators (allow/deny).

Works across client, server or a mix. Also works when a client initiates a collection method and the server runs the hook, all while respecting the collection validators (allow/deny).

  • Simon Fridlund
  • Kelly Copley

Page.title: Fast Render
Page._content:
Fast Render is back!

Fast Render can improve the initial load time of your app, giving you 2-10 times faster initial page loads. It provides the same effect as Server Side Rendering (SSR), but still sends data over the wire to avoid breaking one of Meteor’s core principles.

> This is a continuation of meteorhacks:fast-render by @arunoda

* [Kelly Copley](https://github.com/sponsors/copleykj)

Page.title: PostCSS
Page._content:
Meteor CSS Minifier with PostCSS processing.

This package allows you to use [PostCSS](https://github.com/postcss/postcss) plugins with .css files. You can add your custom plugins by adding Npm packages using `package.json`. You can also use your favourite preprocessor side by side with this package. It allows you to enable many PostCSS plugins, for example Autoprefixer for all preprocessors you use. (Of course you can use it whithout any preprocessor too).

* [Mitar](https://github.com/sponsors/mitar)

Page.title: Publish composite
Page.description: Push notifications for Cordova and browser
Page._content:
`publishComposite(...)` provides a flexible way to publish a set of related documents from various collections using a reactive join. This makes it easy to publish a whole tree of documents at once. The published collections are reactive and will update when additions/changes/deletions are made.

This project differs from many other parent/child relationship mappers in its flexibility. The relationship between a parent and its children can be based on almost anything. For example, let's say you have a site that displays news articles. On each article page, you would like to display a list at the end containing a couple of related articles. You could use `publishComposite` to publish the primary article, scan the body for keywords which are then used to search for other articles, and publish these related articles as children. Of course, the keyword extraction and searching are up to you to implement.

## Managers
* [Sean Dwyer](https://github.com/reywood)
* [Jan Dvorak](https://github.com/sponsors/StorytellerCZ)
* [Kelly Copley](https://github.com/sponsors/copleykj)

## Package
* [GitHub repository](https://github.com/Meteor-Community-Packages/meteor-publish-composite)
* [Packosphere](https://packosphere.com/reywood/publish-composite)

Page.title: Stratosphere
Page._content:
Stratosphere is a private package server for Meteor. So this is like Atmosphere on your own servers, with private packages.

Besides your own packages, Stratosphere will also give you access to all packages on Atmosphere.

At any time you can switch between package servers by setting an environment variable.

## Managers
* [Mitar](https://github.com/sponsors/mitar)
* [Seba Kerchhof](https://github.com/sebakerckhof)
* [Kelly Copley](https://github.com/sponsors/copleykj/)

* [GitHub repository](https://github.com/Meteor-Community-Packages/stratosphere)

Page.title: User status
Page.description: Push notifications for Cordova and browser
Page._content:
Keeps track of user connection data, such as IP addresses, user agents, and client-side activity, and tracks this information in `Meteor.users` as well as some other objects. This allows you to easily see users that are online, for applications such as rendering the users box below showing online users in green and idle users in orange.

## Managers
* [Andrew Mao](https://github.com/mizzao)

## Package
* [GitHub repository](https://github.com/Meteor-Community-Packages/meteor-user-status)

Page.title: Collection Hooks
Page._content:
Extends Mongo.Collection with `before`/`after` hooks for `insert`, `update`, `remove`, `find`, and `findOne`.

Works across client, server or a mix. Also works when a client initiates a collection method and the server runs the hook, all while respecting the collection validators (allow/deny).

## Managers
* [Seba Kerchhof](https://github.com/sebakerckhof)
* [Jan Dvorak](https://github.com/sponsors/StorytellerCZ)
* [Simon Fridlund](https://github.com/sponsors/zimme)
* [Kelly Copley](https://github.com/sponsors/copleykj/)

## Pacakges

* [Atmosphere](https://atmospherejs.com/matb33/collection-hooks)
* [Packosphere](https://packosphere.com/matb33/collection-hooks)

Page.title: Collection 2
Page._content:
A Meteor package that allows you to attach a schema to a Mongo.Collection. Automatically validates against that schema when inserting and updating from client or server code.

This package requires the [simpl-schema NPM package](https://github.com/aldeed/simple-schema-js), which defines the schema syntax and provides the validation logic.

* [Eric Dobbertin](https://github.com/sponsors/aldeed)

- [Atmosphere](https://atmospherejs.com/aldeed/collection2)

Page.title: Fast Render
Page._content:
Fast Render is back!

Fast Render can improve the initial load time of your app, giving you 2-10 times faster initial page loads. It provides the same effect as Server Side Rendering (SSR), but still sends data over the wire to avoid breaking one of Meteor’s core principles.

> This is a continuation of meteorhacks:fast-render by @arunoda

## Managers
* [Kelly Copley](https://github.com/sponsors/copleykj)

## Package
* [GitHub repository](https://github.com/Meteor-Community-Packages/meteor-fast-render)
* [Packosphere](https://packosphere.com/communitypackages/fast-render)

Page.title: PostCSS
Page._content:
Meteor CSS Minifier with PostCSS processing.

This package allows you to use [PostCSS](https://github.com/postcss/postcss) plugins with .css files. You can add your custom plugins by adding Npm packages using `package.json`. You can also use your favourite preprocessor side by side with this package. It allows you to enable many PostCSS plugins, for example Autoprefixer for all preprocessors you use. (Of course you can use it whithout any preprocessor too).

## Managers
* [Kelly Copley](https://github.com/sponsors/copleykj/)
* [Mitar](https://github.com/sponsors/mitar)

## Repository
* [GitHub repository](https://github.com/Meteor-Community-Packages/meteor-postcss)

Page.title: Publish composite
Page.description: Push notifications for Cordova and browser
Page._content:
`publishComposite(...)` provides a flexible way to publish a set of related documents from various collections using a reactive join. This makes it easy to publish a whole tree of documents at once. The published collections are reactive and will update when additions/changes/deletions are made.

This project differs from many other parent/child relationship mappers in its flexibility. The relationship between a parent and its children can be based on almost anything. For example, let's say you have a site that displays news articles. On each article page, you would like to display a list at the end containing a couple of related articles. You could use `publishComposite` to publish the primary article, scan the body for keywords which are then used to search for other articles, and publish these related articles as children. Of course, the keyword extraction and searching are up to you to implement.

## Managers
* [Sean Dwyer](https://github.com/reywood)
* [Jan Dvorak](https://github.com/sponsors/StorytellerCZ)
* [Kelly Copley](https://github.com/sponsors/copleykj)

## Package
* [GitHub repository](https://github.com/Meteor-Community-Packages/meteor-publish-composite)
* [Packosphere](https://packosphere.com/reywood/publish-composite)

Page.title: Stratosphere
Page._content:
Stratosphere is a private package server for Meteor. So this is like Atmosphere on your own servers, with private packages.

Besides your own packages, Stratosphere will also give you access to all packages on Atmosphere.

At any time you can switch between package servers by setting an environment variable.

* [Mitar](https://github.com/sponsors/mitar)

* [Kelly Copley](https://github.com/sponsors/copleykj/)

Page.title: User status
Page.description: Push notifications for Cordova and browser
Page._content:
Keeps track of user connection data, such as IP addresses, user agents, and client-side activity, and tracks this information in `Meteor.users` as well as some other objects. This allows you to easily see users that are online, for applications such as rendering the users box below showing online users in green and idle users in orange.

## Managers
* [Andrew Mao](https://github.com/mizzao)

* [GitHub repository](https://github.com/Meteor-Community-Packages/meteor-user-status)

Page.title: Collection Hooks
Page._content:
Extends Mongo.Collection with `before`/`after` hooks for `insert`, `update`, `remove`, `find`, and `findOne`.

Works across client, server or a mix. Also works when a client initiates a collection method and the server runs the hook, all while respecting the collection validators (allow/deny).

## Managers

* [Jan Dvorak](https://github.com/sponsors/StorytellerCZ)
* [Simon Fridlund](https://github.com/sponsors/zimme)
* [Kelly Copley](https://github.com/sponsors/copleykj/)

Page.title: Collection 2
Page._content:
A Meteor package that allows you to attach a schema to a Mongo.Collection. Automatically validates against that schema when inserting and updating from client or server code.

This package requires the [simpl-schema NPM package](https://github.com/aldeed/simple-schema-js), which defines the schema syntax and provides the validation logic.

Page.title: Fast Render
Page._content:
Fast Render is back!

Fast Render can improve the initial load time of your app, giving you 2-10 times faster initial page loads. It provides the same effect as Server Side Rendering (SSR), but still sends data over the wire to avoid breaking one of Meteor’s core principles.

> This is a continuation of meteorhacks:fast-render by @arunoda

## Managers
* [Kelly Copley](https://github.com/sponsors/copleykj)

## Package
* [GitHub repository](https://github.com/Meteor-Community-Packages/meteor-fast-render)
* [Packosphere](https://packosphere.com/communitypackages/fast-render)

Page.title: Publish composite
Page.description: Push notifications for Cordova and browser
Page._content:
`publishComposite(...)` provides a flexible way to publish a set of related documents from various collections using a reactive join. This makes it easy to publish a whole tree of documents at once. The published collections are reactive and will update when additions/changes/deletions are made.

This project differs from many other parent/child relationship mappers in its flexibility. The relationship between a parent and its children can be based on almost anything. For example, let's say you have a site that displays news articles. On each article page, you would like to display a list at the end containing a couple of related articles. You could use `publishComposite` to publish the primary article, scan the body for keywords which are then used to search for other articles, and publish these related articles as children. Of course, the keyword extraction and searching are up to you to implement.

## Managers
* [Sean Dwyer](https://github.com/reywood)
* [Jan Dvorak](https://github.com/sponsors/StorytellerCZ)
* [Kelly Copley](https://github.com/sponsors/copleykj)

## Package
* [GitHub repository](https://github.com/Meteor-Community-Packages/meteor-publish-composite)
* [Packosphere](https://packosphere.com/reywood/publish-composite)

Page.title: PostCSS
Page._content:
Meteor CSS Minifier with PostCSS processing.

This package allows you to use [PostCSS](https://github.com/postcss/postcss) plugins with .css files. You can add your custom plugins by adding Npm packages using `package.json`. You can also use your favourite preprocessor side by side with this package. It allows you to enable many PostCSS plugins, for example Autoprefixer for all preprocessors you use. (Of course you can use it whithout any preprocessor too).

## Managers
* [Kelly Copley](https://github.com/sponsors/copleykj/)
* [Mitar](https://github.com/sponsors/mitar)

Page.title: Stratosphere
Page._content:
Stratosphere is a private package server for Meteor. So this is like Atmosphere on your own servers, with private packages.

Besides your own packages, Stratosphere will also give you access to all packages on Atmosphere.

At any time you can switch between package servers by setting an environment variable.

Page.title: User status
Page.description: Push notifications for Cordova and browser
Page._content:
Keeps track of user connection data, such as IP addresses, user agents, and client-side activity, and tracks this information in `Meteor.users` as well as some other objects. This allows you to easily see users that are online, for applications such as rendering the users box below showing online users in green and idle users in orange.

## Managers

Page.title: Check NPM version
Page._content:
Enforces "peer" npm dependencies in Meteor packages.

Page.title: Collection Hooks
Page._content:
Extends Mongo.Collection with `before`/`after` hooks for `insert`, `update`, `remove`, `find`, and `findOne`.

Works across client, server or a mix. Also works when a client initiates a collection method and the server runs the hook, all while respecting the collection validators (allow/deny).

Page.title: Fast Render
Page._content:
Fast Render is back!

Fast Render can improve the initial load time of your app, giving you 2-10 times faster initial page loads. It provides the same effect as Server Side Rendering (SSR), but still sends data over the wire to avoid breaking one of Meteor’s core principles.

> This is a continuation of meteorhacks:fast-render by @arunoda

Page._content:
Meteor CSS Minifier with PostCSS processing.

This package allows you to use [PostCSS](https://github.com/postcss/postcss) plugins with .css files. You can add your custom plugins by adding Npm packages using `package.json`. You can also use your favourite preprocessor side by side with this package. It allows you to enable many PostCSS plugins, for example Autoprefixer for all preprocessors you use. (Of course you can use it whithout any preprocessor too).

Page.title: Publish composite
Page.description: Push notifications for Cordova and browser
Page._content:
`publishComposite(...)` provides a flexible way to publish a set of related documents from various collections using a reactive join. This makes it easy to publish a whole tree of documents at once. The published collections are reactive and will update when additions/changes/deletions are made.

This project differs from many other parent/child relationship mappers in its flexibility. The relationship between a parent and its children can be based on almost anything. For example, let's say you have a site that displays news articles. On each article page, you would like to display a list at the end containing a couple of related articles. You could use `publishComposite` to publish the primary article, scan the body for keywords which are then used to search for other articles, and publish these related articles as children. Of course, the keyword extraction and searching are up to you to implement.

## Managers
* [Sean Dwyer](https://github.com/reywood)
* [Jan Dvorak](https://github.com/sponsors/StorytellerCZ)
* [Kelly Copley](https://github.com/sponsors/copleykj)

## Package
* [GitHub repository](https://github.com/Meteor-Community-Packages/meteor-publish-composite)
* [Packosphere](https://packosphere.com/reywood/publish-composite)
Page.raw:
---
title: Publish composite
description: Push notifications for Cordova and browser
---

`publishComposite(...)` provides a flexible way to publish a set of related documents from various collections using a reactive join. This makes it easy to publish a whole tree of documents at once. The published collections are reactive and will update when additions/changes/deletions are made.

This project differs from many other parent/child relationship mappers in its flexibility. The relationship between a parent and its children can be based on almost anything. For example, let's say you have a site that displays news articles. On each article page, you would like to display a list at the end containing a couple of related articles. You could use `publishComposite` to publish the primary article, scan the body for keywords which are then used to search for other articles, and publish these related articles as children. Of course, the keyword extraction and searching are up to you to implement.

## Managers
* [Sean Dwyer](https://github.com/reywood)
* [Jan Dvorak](https://github.com/sponsors/StorytellerCZ)
* [Kelly Copley](https://github.com/sponsors/copleykj)

## Package
* [GitHub repository](https://github.com/Meteor-Community-Packages/meteor-publish-composite)
* [Packosphere](https://packosphere.com/reywood/publish-composite)
Page.content:
publishComposite(...) provides a flexible way to publish a set of related documents from various collections using a reactive join. This makes it easy to publish a whole tree of documents at once. The published collections are reactive and will update when additions/changes/deletions are made.

This project differs from many other parent/child relationship mappers in its flexibility. The relationship between a parent and its children can be based on almost anything. For example, let’s say you have a site that displays news articles. On each article page, you would like to display a list at the end containing a couple of related articles. You could use publishComposite to publish the primary article, scan the body for keywords which are then used to search for other articles, and publish these related articles as children. Of course, the keyword extraction and searching are up to you to implement.

Managers

  • Sean Dwyer
  • Jan Dvorak
  • Kelly Copley

Package

  • GitHub repository
  • Packosphere

Page.title: Stratosphere
Page._content:
Stratosphere is a private package server for Meteor. So this is like Atmosphere on your own servers, with private packages.

Besides your own packages, Stratosphere will also give you access to all packages on Atmosphere.

At any time you can switch between package servers by setting an environment variable.

Page.title: User status
Page.description: Push notifications for Cordova and browser
Page._content:
Keeps track of user connection data, such as IP addresses, user agents, and client-side activity, and tracks this information in `Meteor.users` as well as some other objects. This allows you to easily see users that are online, for applications such as rendering the users box below showing online users in green and idle users in orange.

## Managers
* [Andrew Mao](https://github.com/mizzao)

Page.title: Collection Hooks
Page._content:
Extends Mongo.Collection with `before`/`after` hooks for `insert`, `update`, `remove`, `find`, and `findOne`.

Works across client, server or a mix. Also works when a client initiates a collection method and the server runs the hook, all while respecting the collection validators (allow/deny).

Page.title: Collection 2
Page._content:
A Meteor package that allows you to attach a schema to a Mongo.Collection. Automatically validates against that schema when inserting and updating from client or server code.

This package requires the [simpl-schema NPM package](https://github.com/aldeed/simple-schema-js), which defines the schema syntax and provides the validation logic.

Page.title: Fast Render
Page._content:
Fast Render is back!

Fast Render can improve the initial load time of your app, giving you 2-10 times faster initial page loads. It provides the same effect as Server Side Rendering (SSR), but still sends data over the wire to avoid breaking one of Meteor’s core principles.

> This is a continuation of meteorhacks:fast-render by @arunoda

## Managers
* [Kelly Copley](https://github.com/sponsors/copleykj)

## Package
* [GitHub repository](https://github.com/Meteor-Community-Packages/meteor-fast-render)
* [Packosphere](https://packosphere.com/communitypackages/fast-render)

Page.title: PostCSS
Page._content:
Meteor CSS Minifier with PostCSS processing.

This package allows you to use [PostCSS](https://github.com/postcss/postcss) plugins with .css files. You can add your custom plugins by adding Npm packages using `package.json`. You can also use your favourite preprocessor side by side with this package. It allows you to enable many PostCSS plugins, for example Autoprefixer for all preprocessors you use. (Of course you can use it whithout any preprocessor too).

## Managers
* [Kelly Copley](https://github.com/sponsors/copleykj/)
* [Mitar](https://github.com/sponsors/mitar)

Page.title: Publish composite
Page.description: Push notifications for Cordova and browser
Page._content:
`publishComposite(...)` provides a flexible way to publish a set of related documents from various collections using a reactive join. This makes it easy to publish a whole tree of documents at once. The published collections are reactive and will update when additions/changes/deletions are made.

This project differs from many other parent/child relationship mappers in its flexibility. The relationship between a parent and its children can be based on almost anything. For example, let's say you have a site that displays news articles. On each article page, you would like to display a list at the end containing a couple of related articles. You could use `publishComposite` to publish the primary article, scan the body for keywords which are then used to search for other articles, and publish these related articles as children. Of course, the keyword extraction and searching are up to you to implement.

## Managers
* [Sean Dwyer](https://github.com/reywood)
* [Jan Dvorak](https://github.com/sponsors/StorytellerCZ)
* [Kelly Copley](https://github.com/sponsors/copleykj)

## Package
* [GitHub repository](https://github.com/Meteor-Community-Packages/meteor-publish-composite)
* [Packosphere](https://packosphere.com/reywood/publish-composite)

Page.title: Stratosphere
Page._content:
Stratosphere is a private package server for Meteor. So this is like Atmosphere on your own servers, with private packages.

Besides your own packages, Stratosphere will also give you access to all packages on Atmosphere.

At any time you can switch between package servers by setting an environment variable.

Besides your own packages, Stratosphere will also give you access to all packages on Atmosphere.

At any time you can switch between package servers by setting an environment variable.

Managers

  • Mitar
  • Seba Kerchhof
  • Kelly Copley

Repository

  • GitHub repository

Page.title: User status
Page.description: Push notifications for Cordova and browser
Page._content:
Keeps track of user connection data, such as IP addresses, user agents, and client-side activity, and tracks this information in `Meteor.users` as well as some other objects. This allows you to easily see users that are online, for applications such as rendering the users box below showing online users in green and idle users in orange.

## Managers
* [Andrew Mao](https://github.com/mizzao)

## Package
* [GitHub repository](https://github.com/Meteor-Community-Packages/meteor-user-status)

Page.title: Collection Hooks
Page._content:
Extends Mongo.Collection with `before`/`after` hooks for `insert`, `update`, `remove`, `find`, and `findOne`.

Works across client, server or a mix. Also works when a client initiates a collection method and the server runs the hook, all while respecting the collection validators (allow/deny).

## Managers
* [Seba Kerchhof](https://github.com/sebakerckhof)
* [Jan Dvorak](https://github.com/sponsors/StorytellerCZ)
* [Simon Fridlund](https://github.com/sponsors/zimme)
* [Kelly Copley](https://github.com/sponsors/copleykj/)

## Pacakges
* [GitHub repository](https://github.com/Meteor-Community-Packages/meteor-collection-hooks)
* [Atmosphere](https://atmospherejs.com/matb33/collection-hooks)
* [Packosphere](https://packosphere.com/matb33/collection-hooks)

Page.title: Collection 2
Page._content:
A Meteor package that allows you to attach a schema to a Mongo.Collection. Automatically validates against that schema when inserting and updating from client or server code.

This package requires the [simpl-schema NPM package](https://github.com/aldeed/simple-schema-js), which defines the schema syntax and provides the validation logic.

## Managers
* [Eric Dobbertin](https://github.com/sponsors/aldeed)
* [Jan Dvorak](https://github.com/sponsors/StorytellerCZ)
* [Kelly Copley](https://github.com/sponsors/copleykj)
* [Harry Adel](https://github.com/harryadel)

## Pacakges
- [GitHub repository](https://github.com/Meteor-Community-Packages/meteor-collection2)
- [Atmosphere](https://atmospherejs.com/aldeed/collection2)

Page.title: Fast Render
Page._content:
Fast Render is back!

Fast Render can improve the initial load time of your app, giving you 2-10 times faster initial page loads. It provides the same effect as Server Side Rendering (SSR), but still sends data over the wire to avoid breaking one of Meteor’s core principles.

> This is a continuation of meteorhacks:fast-render by @arunoda

## Managers
* [Kelly Copley](https://github.com/sponsors/copleykj)

## Package
* [GitHub repository](https://github.com/Meteor-Community-Packages/meteor-fast-render)
* [Packosphere](https://packosphere.com/communitypackages/fast-render)

Page.title: PostCSS
Page._content:
Meteor CSS Minifier with PostCSS processing.

This package allows you to use [PostCSS](https://github.com/postcss/postcss) plugins with .css files. You can add your custom plugins by adding Npm packages using `package.json`. You can also use your favourite preprocessor side by side with this package. It allows you to enable many PostCSS plugins, for example Autoprefixer for all preprocessors you use. (Of course you can use it whithout any preprocessor too).

## Managers
* [Kelly Copley](https://github.com/sponsors/copleykj/)
* [Mitar](https://github.com/sponsors/mitar)

Page.title: Publish composite
Page.description: Push notifications for Cordova and browser
Page._content:
`publishComposite(...)` provides a flexible way to publish a set of related documents from various collections using a reactive join. This makes it easy to publish a whole tree of documents at once. The published collections are reactive and will update when additions/changes/deletions are made.

This project differs from many other parent/child relationship mappers in its flexibility. The relationship between a parent and its children can be based on almost anything. For example, let's say you have a site that displays news articles. On each article page, you would like to display a list at the end containing a couple of related articles. You could use `publishComposite` to publish the primary article, scan the body for keywords which are then used to search for other articles, and publish these related articles as children. Of course, the keyword extraction and searching are up to you to implement.

## Managers
* [Sean Dwyer](https://github.com/reywood)
* [Jan Dvorak](https://github.com/sponsors/StorytellerCZ)
* [Kelly Copley](https://github.com/sponsors/copleykj)

## Package
* [GitHub repository](https://github.com/Meteor-Community-Packages/meteor-publish-composite)
* [Packosphere](https://packosphere.com/reywood/publish-composite)

Page.title: Stratosphere
Page._content:
Stratosphere is a private package server for Meteor. So this is like Atmosphere on your own servers, with private packages.

Besides your own packages, Stratosphere will also give you access to all packages on Atmosphere.

At any time you can switch between package servers by setting an environment variable.

Page.title: Collection Hooks
Page._content:
Extends Mongo.Collection with `before`/`after` hooks for `insert`, `update`, `remove`, `find`, and `findOne`.

Works across client, server or a mix. Also works when a client initiates a collection method and the server runs the hook, all while respecting the collection validators (allow/deny).

Page.title: Collection 2
Page._content:
A Meteor package that allows you to attach a schema to a Mongo.Collection. Automatically validates against that schema when inserting and updating from client or server code.

This package requires the [simpl-schema NPM package](https://github.com/aldeed/simple-schema-js), which defines the schema syntax and provides the validation logic.

Page.title: Fast Render
Page._content:
Fast Render is back!

Fast Render can improve the initial load time of your app, giving you 2-10 times faster initial page loads. It provides the same effect as Server Side Rendering (SSR), but still sends data over the wire to avoid breaking one of Meteor’s core principles.

> This is a continuation of meteorhacks:fast-render by @arunoda

## Managers
* [Kelly Copley](https://github.com/sponsors/copleykj)

## Package
* [GitHub repository](https://github.com/Meteor-Community-Packages/meteor-fast-render)
* [Packosphere](https://packosphere.com/communitypackages/fast-render)

Page.title: PostCSS
Page._content:
Meteor CSS Minifier with PostCSS processing.

This package allows you to use [PostCSS](https://github.com/postcss/postcss) plugins with .css files. You can add your custom plugins by adding Npm packages using `package.json`. You can also use your favourite preprocessor side by side with this package. It allows you to enable many PostCSS plugins, for example Autoprefixer for all preprocessors you use. (Of course you can use it whithout any preprocessor too).

Page.title: Publish composite
Page.description: Push notifications for Cordova and browser
Page._content:
`publishComposite(...)` provides a flexible way to publish a set of related documents from various collections using a reactive join. This makes it easy to publish a whole tree of documents at once. The published collections are reactive and will update when additions/changes/deletions are made.

This project differs from many other parent/child relationship mappers in its flexibility. The relationship between a parent and its children can be based on almost anything. For example, let's say you have a site that displays news articles. On each article page, you would like to display a list at the end containing a couple of related articles. You could use `publishComposite` to publish the primary article, scan the body for keywords which are then used to search for other articles, and publish these related articles as children. Of course, the keyword extraction and searching are up to you to implement.

## Managers
* [Sean Dwyer](https://github.com/reywood)
* [Jan Dvorak](https://github.com/sponsors/StorytellerCZ)
* [Kelly Copley](https://github.com/sponsors/copleykj)

## Package
* [GitHub repository](https://github.com/Meteor-Community-Packages/meteor-publish-composite)
* [Packosphere](https://packosphere.com/reywood/publish-composite)

Page.title: Stratosphere
Page._content:
Stratosphere is a private package server for Meteor. So this is like Atmosphere on your own servers, with private packages.

Besides your own packages, Stratosphere will also give you access to all packages on Atmosphere.

At any time you can switch between package servers by setting an environment variable.

* [Mitar](https://github.com/sponsors/mitar)

Page.title: User status
Page.description: Push notifications for Cordova and browser
Page._content:
Keeps track of user connection data, such as IP addresses, user agents, and client-side activity, and tracks this information in `Meteor.users` as well as some other objects. This allows you to easily see users that are online, for applications such as rendering the users box below showing online users in green and idle users in orange.

## Managers
* [Andrew Mao](https://github.com/mizzao)

Page.title: Collection Hooks
Page._content:
Extends Mongo.Collection with `before`/`after` hooks for `insert`, `update`, `remove`, `find`, and `findOne`.

Works across client, server or a mix. Also works when a client initiates a collection method and the server runs the hook, all while respecting the collection validators (allow/deny).

Works across client, server or a mix. Also works when a client initiates a collection method and the server runs the hook, all while respecting the collection validators (allow/deny).

  • Seba Kerchhof
  • Jan Dvorak
  • Simon Fridlund
  • Kelly Copley

Pacakges

  • GitHub repository
  • Atmosphere
  • Packosphere

Page.title: Fast Render
Page._content:
Fast Render is back!

Fast Render can improve the initial load time of your app, giving you 2-10 times faster initial page loads. It provides the same effect as Server Side Rendering (SSR), but still sends data over the wire to avoid breaking one of Meteor’s core principles.

> This is a continuation of meteorhacks:fast-render by @arunoda

## Managers
* [Kelly Copley](https://github.com/sponsors/copleykj)

Page.title: PostCSS
Page._content:
Meteor CSS Minifier with PostCSS processing.

This package allows you to use [PostCSS](https://github.com/postcss/postcss) plugins with .css files. You can add your custom plugins by adding Npm packages using `package.json`. You can also use your favourite preprocessor side by side with this package. It allows you to enable many PostCSS plugins, for example Autoprefixer for all preprocessors you use. (Of course you can use it whithout any preprocessor too).

## Managers
* [Kelly Copley](https://github.com/sponsors/copleykj/)
* [Mitar](https://github.com/sponsors/mitar)

Page.title: Publish composite
Page.description: Push notifications for Cordova and browser
Page._content:
`publishComposite(...)` provides a flexible way to publish a set of related documents from various collections using a reactive join. This makes it easy to publish a whole tree of documents at once. The published collections are reactive and will update when additions/changes/deletions are made.

This project differs from many other parent/child relationship mappers in its flexibility. The relationship between a parent and its children can be based on almost anything. For example, let's say you have a site that displays news articles. On each article page, you would like to display a list at the end containing a couple of related articles. You could use `publishComposite` to publish the primary article, scan the body for keywords which are then used to search for other articles, and publish these related articles as children. Of course, the keyword extraction and searching are up to you to implement.

## Managers
* [Sean Dwyer](https://github.com/reywood)
* [Jan Dvorak](https://github.com/sponsors/StorytellerCZ)
* [Kelly Copley](https://github.com/sponsors/copleykj)

## Package
* [GitHub repository](https://github.com/Meteor-Community-Packages/meteor-publish-composite)
* [Packosphere](https://packosphere.com/reywood/publish-composite)

Page.title: Stratosphere
Page._content:
Stratosphere is a private package server for Meteor. So this is like Atmosphere on your own servers, with private packages.

Besides your own packages, Stratosphere will also give you access to all packages on Atmosphere.

At any time you can switch between package servers by setting an environment variable.

## Managers
* [Mitar](https://github.com/sponsors/mitar)
* [Seba Kerchhof](https://github.com/sebakerckhof)
* [Kelly Copley](https://github.com/sponsors/copleykj/)

Page.title: User status
Page.description: Push notifications for Cordova and browser
Page._content:
Keeps track of user connection data, such as IP addresses, user agents, and client-side activity, and tracks this information in `Meteor.users` as well as some other objects. This allows you to easily see users that are online, for applications such as rendering the users box below showing online users in green and idle users in orange.

## Managers
* [Andrew Mao](https://github.com/mizzao)

## Package
* [GitHub repository](https://github.com/Meteor-Community-Packages/meteor-user-status)

Page.title: Collection Hooks
Page._content:
Extends Mongo.Collection with `before`/`after` hooks for `insert`, `update`, `remove`, `find`, and `findOne`.

Works across client, server or a mix. Also works when a client initiates a collection method and the server runs the hook, all while respecting the collection validators (allow/deny).

## Managers
* [Seba Kerchhof](https://github.com/sebakerckhof)
* [Jan Dvorak](https://github.com/sponsors/StorytellerCZ)
* [Simon Fridlund](https://github.com/sponsors/zimme)
* [Kelly Copley](https://github.com/sponsors/copleykj/)

## Pacakges

* [Atmosphere](https://atmospherejs.com/matb33/collection-hooks)

Page.title: Collection 2
Page._content:
A Meteor package that allows you to attach a schema to a Mongo.Collection. Automatically validates against that schema when inserting and updating from client or server code.

This package requires the [simpl-schema NPM package](https://github.com/aldeed/simple-schema-js), which defines the schema syntax and provides the validation logic.

- [Atmosphere](https://atmospherejs.com/aldeed/collection2)

Page.title: Fast Render
Page._content:
Fast Render is back!

Fast Render can improve the initial load time of your app, giving you 2-10 times faster initial page loads. It provides the same effect as Server Side Rendering (SSR), but still sends data over the wire to avoid breaking one of Meteor’s core principles.

> This is a continuation of meteorhacks:fast-render by @arunoda

## Managers
* [Kelly Copley](https://github.com/sponsors/copleykj)

## Package
* [GitHub repository](https://github.com/Meteor-Community-Packages/meteor-fast-render)
* [Packosphere](https://packosphere.com/communitypackages/fast-render)

Page.title: PostCSS
Page._content:
Meteor CSS Minifier with PostCSS processing.

This package allows you to use [PostCSS](https://github.com/postcss/postcss) plugins with .css files. You can add your custom plugins by adding Npm packages using `package.json`. You can also use your favourite preprocessor side by side with this package. It allows you to enable many PostCSS plugins, for example Autoprefixer for all preprocessors you use. (Of course you can use it whithout any preprocessor too).

## Managers
* [Kelly Copley](https://github.com/sponsors/copleykj/)
* [Mitar](https://github.com/sponsors/mitar)

## Repository
* [GitHub repository](https://github.com/Meteor-Community-Packages/meteor-postcss)

Page.title: Publish composite
Page.description: Push notifications for Cordova and browser
Page._content:
`publishComposite(...)` provides a flexible way to publish a set of related documents from various collections using a reactive join. This makes it easy to publish a whole tree of documents at once. The published collections are reactive and will update when additions/changes/deletions are made.

This project differs from many other parent/child relationship mappers in its flexibility. The relationship between a parent and its children can be based on almost anything. For example, let's say you have a site that displays news articles. On each article page, you would like to display a list at the end containing a couple of related articles. You could use `publishComposite` to publish the primary article, scan the body for keywords which are then used to search for other articles, and publish these related articles as children. Of course, the keyword extraction and searching are up to you to implement.

## Managers
* [Sean Dwyer](https://github.com/reywood)
* [Jan Dvorak](https://github.com/sponsors/StorytellerCZ)
* [Kelly Copley](https://github.com/sponsors/copleykj)

## Package
* [GitHub repository](https://github.com/Meteor-Community-Packages/meteor-publish-composite)
* [Packosphere](https://packosphere.com/reywood/publish-composite)

Page.title: Stratosphere
Page._content:
Stratosphere is a private package server for Meteor. So this is like Atmosphere on your own servers, with private packages.

Besides your own packages, Stratosphere will also give you access to all packages on Atmosphere.

At any time you can switch between package servers by setting an environment variable.

* [Kelly Copley](https://github.com/sponsors/copleykj/)

Page.title: User status
Page.description: Push notifications for Cordova and browser
Page._content:
Keeps track of user connection data, such as IP addresses, user agents, and client-side activity, and tracks this information in `Meteor.users` as well as some other objects. This allows you to easily see users that are online, for applications such as rendering the users box below showing online users in green and idle users in orange.

## Managers
* [Andrew Mao](https://github.com/mizzao)

## Package
* [GitHub repository](https://github.com/Meteor-Community-Packages/meteor-user-status)

Page.title: Collection Hooks
Page._content:
Extends Mongo.Collection with `before`/`after` hooks for `insert`, `update`, `remove`, `find`, and `findOne`.

Works across client, server or a mix. Also works when a client initiates a collection method and the server runs the hook, all while respecting the collection validators (allow/deny).

## Managers
* [Seba Kerchhof](https://github.com/sebakerckhof)
* [Jan Dvorak](https://github.com/sponsors/StorytellerCZ)
* [Simon Fridlund](https://github.com/sponsors/zimme)
* [Kelly Copley](https://github.com/sponsors/copleykj/)

Page.title: Collection 2
Page._content:
A Meteor package that allows you to attach a schema to a Mongo.Collection. Automatically validates against that schema when inserting and updating from client or server code.

This package requires the [simpl-schema NPM package](https://github.com/aldeed/simple-schema-js), which defines the schema syntax and provides the validation logic.

## Managers

* [Kelly Copley](https://github.com/sponsors/copleykj)
* [Harry Adel](https://github.com/harryadel)

- [Atmosphere](https://atmospherejs.com/aldeed/collection2)

Page.title: Fast Render
Page._content:
Fast Render is back!

Fast Render can improve the initial load time of your app, giving you 2-10 times faster initial page loads. It provides the same effect as Server Side Rendering (SSR), but still sends data over the wire to avoid breaking one of Meteor’s core principles.

> This is a continuation of meteorhacks:fast-render by @arunoda

## Managers
* [Kelly Copley](https://github.com/sponsors/copleykj)

## Package
* [GitHub repository](https://github.com/Meteor-Community-Packages/meteor-fast-render)
* [Packosphere](https://packosphere.com/communitypackages/fast-render)

Page.title: PostCSS
Page._content:
Meteor CSS Minifier with PostCSS processing.

This package allows you to use [PostCSS](https://github.com/postcss/postcss) plugins with .css files. You can add your custom plugins by adding Npm packages using `package.json`. You can also use your favourite preprocessor side by side with this package. It allows you to enable many PostCSS plugins, for example Autoprefixer for all preprocessors you use. (Of course you can use it whithout any preprocessor too).

* [Mitar](https://github.com/sponsors/mitar)

Page.title: Publish composite
Page.description: Push notifications for Cordova and browser
Page._content:
`publishComposite(...)` provides a flexible way to publish a set of related documents from various collections using a reactive join. This makes it easy to publish a whole tree of documents at once. The published collections are reactive and will update when additions/changes/deletions are made.

This project differs from many other parent/child relationship mappers in its flexibility. The relationship between a parent and its children can be based on almost anything. For example, let's say you have a site that displays news articles. On each article page, you would like to display a list at the end containing a couple of related articles. You could use `publishComposite` to publish the primary article, scan the body for keywords which are then used to search for other articles, and publish these related articles as children. Of course, the keyword extraction and searching are up to you to implement.

## Managers
* [Sean Dwyer](https://github.com/reywood)
* [Jan Dvorak](https://github.com/sponsors/StorytellerCZ)
* [Kelly Copley](https://github.com/sponsors/copleykj)

## Package
* [GitHub repository](https://github.com/Meteor-Community-Packages/meteor-publish-composite)
* [Packosphere](https://packosphere.com/reywood/publish-composite)

Page.title: Stratosphere
Page._content:
Stratosphere is a private package server for Meteor. So this is like Atmosphere on your own servers, with private packages.

Besides your own packages, Stratosphere will also give you access to all packages on Atmosphere.

At any time you can switch between package servers by setting an environment variable.

Page.title: User status
Page.description: Push notifications for Cordova and browser
Page._content:
Keeps track of user connection data, such as IP addresses, user agents, and client-side activity, and tracks this information in `Meteor.users` as well as some other objects. This allows you to easily see users that are online, for applications such as rendering the users box below showing online users in green and idle users in orange.

Use this package if you are writing an Meteor package that depends on a given npm package is installed at the app level of projects you are installed in.

Page._content:
Extends Mongo.Collection with `before`/`after` hooks for `insert`, `update`, `remove`, `find`, and `findOne`.

Page.title: Fast Render
Page._content:
Fast Render is back!

Fast Render can improve the initial load time of your app, giving you 2-10 times faster initial page loads. It provides the same effect as Server Side Rendering (SSR), but still sends data over the wire to avoid breaking one of Meteor’s core principles.

> This is a continuation of meteorhacks:fast-render by @arunoda

## Managers
* [Kelly Copley](https://github.com/sponsors/copleykj)

Page.title: PostCSS
Page._content:
Meteor CSS Minifier with PostCSS processing.

This package allows you to use [PostCSS](https://github.com/postcss/postcss) plugins with .css files. You can add your custom plugins by adding Npm packages using `package.json`. You can also use your favourite preprocessor side by side with this package. It allows you to enable many PostCSS plugins, for example Autoprefixer for all preprocessors you use. (Of course you can use it whithout any preprocessor too).

Page.title: Publish composite
Page.description: Push notifications for Cordova and browser
Page._content:
`publishComposite(...)` provides a flexible way to publish a set of related documents from various collections using a reactive join. This makes it easy to publish a whole tree of documents at once. The published collections are reactive and will update when additions/changes/deletions are made.

This project differs from many other parent/child relationship mappers in its flexibility. The relationship between a parent and its children can be based on almost anything. For example, let's say you have a site that displays news articles. On each article page, you would like to display a list at the end containing a couple of related articles. You could use `publishComposite` to publish the primary article, scan the body for keywords which are then used to search for other articles, and publish these related articles as children. Of course, the keyword extraction and searching are up to you to implement.

## Managers
* [Sean Dwyer](https://github.com/reywood)
* [Jan Dvorak](https://github.com/sponsors/StorytellerCZ)
* [Kelly Copley](https://github.com/sponsors/copleykj)

## Package
* [GitHub repository](https://github.com/Meteor-Community-Packages/meteor-publish-composite)
* [Packosphere](https://packosphere.com/reywood/publish-composite)
Page.raw:
---
title: Publish composite
description: Push notifications for Cordova and browser
---

`publishComposite(...)` provides a flexible way to publish a set of related documents from various collections using a reactive join. This makes it easy to publish a whole tree of documents at once. The published collections are reactive and will update when additions/changes/deletions are made.

This project differs from many other parent/child relationship mappers in its flexibility. The relationship between a parent and its children can be based on almost anything. For example, let's say you have a site that displays news articles. On each article page, you would like to display a list at the end containing a couple of related articles. You could use `publishComposite` to publish the primary article, scan the body for keywords which are then used to search for other articles, and publish these related articles as children. Of course, the keyword extraction and searching are up to you to implement.

## Managers
* [Sean Dwyer](https://github.com/reywood)
* [Jan Dvorak](https://github.com/sponsors/StorytellerCZ)
* [Kelly Copley](https://github.com/sponsors/copleykj)

## Package
* [GitHub repository](https://github.com/Meteor-Community-Packages/meteor-publish-composite)
* [Packosphere](https://packosphere.com/reywood/publish-composite)
Page.content:
publishComposite(...) provides a flexible way to publish a set of related documents from various collections using a reactive join. This makes it easy to publish a whole tree of documents at once. The published collections are reactive and will update when additions/changes/deletions are made.

This project differs from many other parent/child relationship mappers in its flexibility. The relationship between a parent and its children can be based on almost anything. For example, let’s say you have a site that displays news articles. On each article page, you would like to display a list at the end containing a couple of related articles. You could use publishComposite to publish the primary article, scan the body for keywords which are then used to search for other articles, and publish these related articles as children. Of course, the keyword extraction and searching are up to you to implement.

Managers

  • Sean Dwyer
  • Jan Dvorak
  • Kelly Copley

Package

  • GitHub repository
  • Packosphere
